name: p-anisidine
Reason: Starting with the fundamental unit aniline, which has a melting point of around -6 degrees Celsius, we consider the functional groups present in p-anisidine. The addition of a methoxy group (OCH3) in the para position generally increases the melting point due to a rise in molecular weight and the electron-donating effect leading to an increased stabilization of the crystal lattice structure. A methoxy group typically adds about 20-25 degrees Celsius to the melting point of an aromatic compound. Furthermore, the methyl group contributes to the steric hindrance and increased molecular weight, which can further increase the melting point by a smaller increment, approximately 1-5 degrees Celsius.

name: p-anisidine
Reason: Starting with the fundamental unit of aniline, which has a melting point of around -6 degrees Celsius, the addition of a methoxy group (OCH3) in the para position influences the melting point. The methoxy group increases the melting point due to a rise in molecular weight and electron-donating effects, which can lead to an increased stabilization of the crystal lattice structure through additional hydrogen bonding and dipole-dipole interactions. Based on previous knowledge of similar aromatic compounds, a methoxy group typically adds about 20-25 degrees Celsius to the melting point. Thus, considering the actual value of p-anisidine's melting point is 58.5 degrees Celsius, the predicted increase caused by the methoxy group should be adjusted to match the actual value.
